children.name: the difference between two people or things
difference
children.definition: the amount by which one person, thing, or amount is different from another: khác biệt
examples: difference between
Calculate the difference between the amount you started with and what you have left.
difference in
There was fifteen years difference in age between the two women.
cultural/political/regional etc differencesthe major cultural differences between the west and the east
age/ height/ price etc differencebetween one amount and another
I prefer the Peugeot 406 to the 405. What’s the price difference?

children.name: a big/major/huge difference
examples: I think you’ll notice a big difference.

children.name: an important/significant/crucial difference
examples: A study of the two groups of students showed a significant difference.

children.name: a slight/small/minor difference
examples: There’s only a slight difference between the male and the female bird.

children.name: a marked/dramatic difference
examples: There was a marked difference between the two sets of results.

children.name: a subtle difference
examples: There’s a subtle difference in flavour between these coffees.

children.name: an essential/fundamental difference
examples: The fundamental differences between the two sides slowly emerged.

children.name: class differences
examples: People’s answers to the questions showed clear class differences.

children.name: sex/gender differences
examples: gender differences in levels of criminality

children.name: individual differences
examples: We respect the children’s individual differences.

children.name: pay the difference
examples: If you put all your savings towards the cost of a bike, your Dad and I will pay the difference.

children.name: contrast
children.definition: a difference between people, ideas, situations, things etc that are being compared :sự tương phản trái ngược
examples: While there are similarities in the two cultures, there are also great contrasts.
contrast between
the economic and social contrasts between the poor and the rich
contrast with
The marble is smooth and polished, making a strong contrast with the worn stonework around it.
by contrast (to/with)
The birth rate for older women has declined, but, by contrast, births to teenage mothers have increased.
in contrast (to/with)
The stock lost 60 cents a share, in contrast to last year, when it gained 21 cents.
(in) stark/marked/sharp etc contrast to sth
The winter heat wave in California is a stark contrast to the below-freezing temperatures on the East Coast.
The spirited mood on Friday was in sharp contrast to the tense atmosphere last week.
The approach to learning at this school stands in marked contrast to the traditional methods used at other schools nearby.
an interesting contrastthe interesting contrast between his early and later paintings

children.name: a complete/total contrast
examples: A complete contrast in building style can be seen in Commercial Road.

children.name: a sharp/stark/strong contrast
examples: There is a sharp contrast between the type of people who read the two newspapers.

children.name: a marked/striking contrast
examples: I noticed a marked contrast in his behaviour before and after treatment.

children.name: a startling contrast
examples: The big modern factories make a startling contrast to the opposite side of the road.

children.name: a dramatic contrast
examples: Alaska is a land of dramatic contrast.

children.name: a clear/obvious contrast
examples: There was a clear contrast between the father and the son.

children.name: make a contrast
examples: The fruit and the meat make a delicious contrast of flavours.

children.name: draw a contrast
examples: It is tempting to draw sharp contrasts between religion and science.

children.name: provide/offer contrast
examples: The plant is very attractive, and provides excellent contrast to other plants.

children.name: highlight a contrast
examples: The research will highlight the contrasts between different approaches to taxation.

children.name: stand in sharp/stark etc contrast to sth
examples: The mountains stand in stark contrast to the area around them.

children.name: in direct contrast to sb/sth
children.definition: completely different to something or someone
examples: She’s fun and warm and amusing – in direct contrast to James.

children.name: in sharp/stark etc contrast
examples: We are still getting some sun, in marked contrast to last year’s everlasting grey skies.

children.name: gap
children.definition: a big difference between two situations, amounts, groups of people etc :cách biệt lớn
examples: gap between
the widening gap between the rich and the poor

children.name: a big/large/wide gap
examples: There’s a big gap between the two test scores.

children.name: a huge/substantial etc gap
examples: A huge gap exists between the life styles of the rich and the poor.

children.name: a narrow gap
examples: There’s only a narrow gap between the two candidates in the polls.

children.name: a yawning gap
examples: There’s a yawning gap between the earnings of men and women.

children.name: a growing/widening gap
examples: There is a widening gap in the academic performance of boys and girls.

children.name: an unbridgeable gap
children.definition: a gap that cannot be closed
examples: He felt that there was an unbridgeable gap between the negotiating positions of the two sides.

children.name: a trade gap
children.definition: the difference between the amount a country imports and exports
examples: Britain’s trade gap almost doubled last month.

children.name: the gender gap
children.definition: the difference between men and women
examples: The gender gap was visible in the way men and women voted during the presidential elections.

children.name: the generation gap
children.definition: the difference in attitudes, tastes etc between older and younger people
examples: Taste in music is a good indicator of the generation gap.

children.name: an age gap
children.definition: a difference in age between two people
examples: Despite the age gap, they became good friends.

children.name: a cultural gap
examples: There is a cultural gap between Europe and America on this subject.

children.name: bridge/close/narrow the gap
children.definition: reduce the amount or importance of a difference
examples: The book aims to bridge the gap between theory and practice.|The policies are designed to close the gap between rich and poor.

children.name: the gap narrows
examples: Polls show the gap between the two candidates has narrowed.

children.name: widen the gap
examples: Technology has widened the gap between people with and without computer skills.

children.name: the gap widens
examples: The gap is widening between the incomes of the rich and the less well-off.

children.name: a gap exists
examples: A cultural gap exists between the older and the younger generations.

children.name: gulf
children.definition: a very big difference and lack of understanding between two groups of people, especially in their beliefs, opinions, and way of life:hố sâu ngăn cách
examples: gulf between
the huge gulf between management and unions
a growing gulf between old and young
More riots led to a growing gulf between the police and the communities in which they worked.
bridge/ cross the gulfimprove understanding and communication
The central problem was how to bridge the gulf between the warring factions of the party.

children.name: divide
children.definition: a difference between two groups of people, especially in their beliefs, opinions, and way of life which means they will never be friends, become the same etc: “đường phân thủy”
examples: TheNorth/South divideis characteristic of Britain.
divide between
Recently the divide between the two sides has widened.
cultural/political/racial etc divide
people on bothsides of thepoliticaldivide
There is still a great economic and political divide between the east and the west of the country.

children.name: disparity
children.definition: formal a big difference between two groups of people or things - use this especially when you think the difference is unfair or may cause problems:sự khác biệt, chênh lệch
examples: disparity in/between
a disparity between the rates of pay for men and women
It is not easy to explain the disparity that still exists between the salaries of men and women.
the disparity in wealth between the highest and the lowest employees
the economic/income etc disparity:
The economic disparity between the area’s black and white citizens is a serious problem.

children.name: a fact or quality that makes sb/sth different
difference
children.definition: a detail, fact, or quality that makes one person or thing different from another: điểm khác biệt
examples: We should think about the similarities between cultures, not the differences.

children.name: show a difference
examples: Our data showed considerable national differences.

children.name: know the difference
children.definition: know how two things are different
examples: If you don’t know the difference between two words, your dictionary can help.

children.name: can tell/see the difference
children.definition: can recognize how two things are different
examples: I can’t really see the difference between these two colours.

children.name: notice a difference
examples: She has noticed a dramatic difference in her energy levels.

children.name: spot the difference
examples: It’s easy to spot the difference between real and imitation leather.

children.name: difference between
examples: Try and spot the differences between these two pictures.
The difference between the two cheeses is that one is made from goat’s milk.

children.name: difference in
examples: I don’t think there’s any difference in the way you pronounce these two words.

children.name: know the difference
examples: He’s speaking Italian, not Spanish. Don’t you know the difference?

children.name: distinction
children.definition: a clear difference or separation between two similar things :nét phân biệt
examples: Pablo insists that he is Basque, not Spanish - an important distinction.
distinction between
the distinction between formal and informal language
clear/sharp distinction
There is often no clear distinction between an allergy and food intolerance.
make/draw a distinction
The Actmakes no distinctionbetween children and adults(= it treats them as if they were the same ).
RegisterIn written English, people often usedraw a distinctionrather thanmake a distinction, because it sounds more formal:
The lawdraws a distinctionbetween temporary and permanent employees.

children.name: make a distinction
examples: (= say or show that one exists )It isn’t easy to make a distinction between these two words.

children.name: blur the distinction between something and something
examples: Both sides in the war had been blurring the distinction between military and civilian targets.

children.name: see a distinction
examples: He saw no distinction between religious beliefs and superstition.

children.name: a clear distinction
examples: The legal system makes a clear distinction between adults and children.

children.name: a fine/subtle distinction
examples: Language enables us to make fine distinctions between similar ideas.

children.name: a sharp distinction
examples: The President drew a sharp distinction between his party and the Republican Party.

children.name: an important/crucial distinction
examples: There is an important distinction between these two types of cancer.

children.name: a fundamental distinction
examples: There is a fundamental distinction between authors and readers.

children.name: a useful distinction
examples: He makes a useful distinction between the two theories.

children.name: distinguishing feature
children.definition: /mark/characteristic a feature of a particular person or thing that makes them look different from other similar people or things:nét đặc trưng
examples: The distinguishing feature of the African elephant is the size of its ears.
The melodies of most composers have distinguishing characteristics which make them instantly identifiable.

children.name: similarity
examples: The author notes the similarity between Western and Chinese principles and sees them as having a common basis in science.
similarity with/to
We were able to tell the date of the statue because of its similarity with other statues of that period.
the song’sclose similarityto traditional Jewish music
the similarity of sth (to sth)
For generations, scientists and science-fiction writers talked about the similarity of Mars to Earth.
the similarity ends(= there are no other similarities )Both artists work on a small scale, but there the similarity ends.

children.name: resemblance
children.definition: if there is a resemblance between two people or things, they are similar, especially in in appearance: sự giống nhau, tương tự, tương đồng
examples: When you look at this painting and the one by Rembrandt, there is certainly a resemblance.

children.name: a close resemblance
examples: The vase bore a close resemblance to one owned by my mother.

children.name: a strong resemblance
examples: This slender, feathery herb has a strong resemblance to fennel.

children.name: a striking resemblance
examples: There's a striking resemblance between the two boys.

children.name: a remarkable resemblance
examples: Everyone notices the remarkable resemblance between Mathilda and Anne.

children.name: an uncanny resemblance
examples: I'd always thought that Jo and Freddie had an uncanny resemblance.

children.name: a slight/faint resemblance
examples: Don't you think she has a slight resemblance to that blonde singer in Abba?

children.name: a passing resemblance
examples: There was no more than a passing resemblance between the sisters.

children.name: a superficial resemblance
children.definition: when something seems to look like something else, but is in fact quite different
examples: Its spines give it a superficial resemblance to a hedgehog.

children.name: somebody's physical resemblance to somebody
examples: People often commented on his physical resemblance to his father.

children.name: a family resemblance
children.definition: between members of the same family
examples: I couldn't detect any family resemblance.

children.name: bear/have a resemblance to somebody/something
examples: People said he bore a striking resemblance to the President.

children.name: bear little/no resemblance to somebody/something
examples: He bore little resemblance to the photograph in the newspaper.

children.name: there the resemblance ends
children.definition: they are not similar in any other way
examples: They are both strong-minded women, but there the resemblance ends.

children.name: resemblance between
examples: The resemblance between Susan and her sister was remarkable.

children.name: bear a (close/striking/uncanny etc) resemblance to somebody/something(= look like )
examples: Tina bears a striking resemblance to her mother.

children.name: bear little/no resemblance to somebody/something
examples: What happens in the film bears little resemblance to what actually happened.

children.name: a particular way in which things or people are similar
similarity
children.definition: if there is a similarity between two things or people, they are similar in some way:

children.name: a remarkable/striking/marked similarity
examples: This ape's facial expressions show remarkable similarities to ours.

children.name: a close/great/strong similarity
examples: There was a close similarity between his and Smith's views on education.

children.name: a certain similarity
examples: There are certain similarities between the two theories.

children.name: a superficial similarity
children.definition: one in which an obvious feature of two things is similar, but other features are not similar
examples: the superficial similarities between animal behaviour and human behaviour

children.name: an apparent similarity
children.definition: one that seems similar but really is not
examples: Many apparent similarities became less convincing on closer examination.

children.name: there is a similarity between things
examples: There are lots of similarities between the two bikes.

children.name: bear a/some similarity to something
examples: The murder bore a striking similarity to another shooting 25 miles away.

children.name: have similarities
examples: The two towns have many similarities.

children.name: show similarities
examples: Twins who are raised apart still show similarities in their behaviour.

children.name: similarity between
examples: There are somestriking similaritiesbetween the two plays.

children.name: similarity to
examples: The present crisisbearssomesimilarity tothe oil crisis of the 1970s.

children.name: similarity in
examples: I was struck by the similarities in their early lives.

children.name: similarity with
examples: The police are checking for similarities with other recent attacks in the area.
There are similaritieswith German, though Yiddish is a distinct language.
They are both blonde, butthere the similarity ends.

children.name: parallel
children.definition: a relationship or similarity between two things, especially things that exist or happen in different places or at different times : tương tự, tương đương

children.name: parallel with
examples: Entering the world of fine art, she found many parallels with the world of fashion.

children.name: parallel between
examples: There are many parallels between Yeats and the Romantic poets.

children.name: books that attempt todraw parallelsbetween brains and computers
examples: There are certain parallels between the situation in Europe today and that which existed 90 years ago.
Kakar finds parallels between the Hindi film and popular myths.
